Award.AwardTitle: E-Communities: Investigating how a collaboration between STEM educators and engineers impact underserved youth's participation in engineering design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
E-Communities is a project that will advance efforts to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) through the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program. The project is investigating whether combining the expertise of professional engineers with that of STEM educators will enable classroom mathematics and science teachers to engage students in the engineering design process in ways that affect students' awareness, interest, and ability to identity with engineering principles and careers. Ninety (90) middle school teachers and more than 9000 students from Prince George's County, Maryland will participate in the study. To prepare for the implementation of E-Communities, teachers will engage in face-to-face and virtual professional development to learn how to adapt and integrate this model into their existing instructional practices. Teachers will also collaborate with STEM educators to train engineers for their roles in E-Communities. They will also participate in social network activities with engineers and STEM educators from diverse careers and ethnic backgrounds to support student engagement in the engineering design process. The overall mission of E-Communities is to increase teachers' ability to prepare students to participate fully in STEM careers at the post-secondary level.

This project will use a mixed-method design that consists of pre/post measures, surveys, and a case study. The study is collecting data on the benefits of collaborations among participating middle school leaders, teachers, and students; STEM educators; engineers; and engineering outreach offices to assess the influence of the engineering design model on teachers and students. Products developed through this project will include web broadcasts between engineers and students, teacher-developed lessons that highlight engineering-related mathematics and science practices, and instructional materials useful in engaging middle school students in the engineering design process. Access to the products and other information will be available through online resources, publications, and dissemination at mathematics and science education conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

E-Communities is a strategies project that supports middle school teachers in understanding and implementing the mathematics and science practices outlined in the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) and the Next Generation Standards (NGSS). E-Communities investigated how the engineering design process (EDP) and experiences with professional engineers and STEM educators can be used to (i) increase teachers’ implementation of mathematics and science practices and (ii) awareness of engineering careers. Further, this project addresses how classroom activities affect students’ awareness, interest, and identification with engineering careers and how engineers use EDP. This early design and development study developed and piloted with over 40 middle school math and science teachers and nearly 2000 of their students in Prince George’s County, Maryland.  The strategies utilized to meet the objectives of the project included: 1)STEM educators provide face-to-face (F2F) teacher professional development (PD) on adapting engineering design challenges in culturally responsive ways to teach practice standards in middle school math and science classrooms through EDP; 2) Teachers share their implementation successes and failures of EDP with other teachers and STEM educators during synchronous and asynchronous online professional development to improve knowledge of math and science practices; 3) Teachers participate in a social network platform with engineers and STEM educators to support implementation of engineering design challenges; 4) STEM educators train engineers to communicate their career practices to teachers and students through narrating a professional storyboard; 5) Teachers participate in conversations with engineers about career-related responsibilities, how the EDP is used in careers, and how connections can be drawn between EDP and middle school math and science practice standards through synchronous online collaborations and face-to-face professional development; 6) Engineers of color serve as role models to middle school students by communicating professional information and engaging in career discussions with students virtually online and in-person in classrooms; and 7) Students participate in engineering design challenges in their math and science classes that connect to their interest and values, and to community-based social justice issues. 

 

Intellectual Merit & Broader Impact

One project outcome advancing the theoretical and methodological understandings of Critical Race Theory and Design-Based Implementation Research. We conceptualized Critical Race Design (CRD; Khalil & Kier, 2017; 2018; 2021) as a an emerging anti-racist framework that centers race and equity at the nucleus of educational opportunities by iterative design. E-Communities’ critical race design of a culturally responsive engineering model was informed the beliefs, experiences, and feedback of nearly 50 math/science teachers and their ~2000 middle school students. We showed that if teachers create engineering design challenges contextualized by a lesson that includes the story of a engineer of color, opportunities for students to discuss their lived experiences relative to a social problem, and selected concepts within their curriculum, then teachers would be more efficacious in incorporating the engineering design and students would develop stronger interest in STEM careers (Khalil & Kier, 2018; Kier & Khalil, 2018). We also demonstrated this model must not only be context-specific but also valuable to the community, iterative, and flexible in nature to ultimately community-based problems includingsocial and racial justice issues relevant to the global south. By operationalizing  community cultural wealth as pedagogical resources that can support STEM engagement (Khalil et al, 2021), we conceptualized empathy as integral to design thinking  when solving not only tasks, but also systemic problems of practice faced by STEM education leaders (Khalil & Kier, 2021). We described how equity-centered design thinking around culturally responsive engineering design challenges requires the utility of disciplinary math and science practice standards as well as research-based equitable mathematics teaching practices (Khalil, Bruce & Kier, 2019). We delved deeper into how E-Communities, as an HBCU Research-Practice Partnership, draws upon similar contextual supports that HBCUs use to foster engagement among their postsecondary student population. As a design-based implementation research study within a Black-majority school district, we explain how E-Communities sought to iteratively disrupt and transform inequitable K-12 learning spaces by connecting HBCU teacher educators, science and mathematics teachers of color, STEM professionals of color, and minoritized students by employing a blended model of online and face to face collaborative engagement tools (Kier & Khalil, 2018). Additionally, STEM professional’s online service learning and teachers’ professional learning experiences empowered all to engage minoritized students by interrogating inequities and designing solutions for real-world problems. The knowledge, assets, and insights shared by community stakeholders in both content and practices-- through engineering design processes and tasks-- inflused cultural relevance in both the process and product. Given teachers’ demonstrated a significant increase in self-efficacy of teaching engineering and students showed significantly higher differences across STEM interest survey domains (i.e., science, technology, engineering, math, career goals, and real-world connection), we believe this project can serve as a critical model for P-20 educators seeking meaningful STEM partnerships with minoritized communities.
